awd_titl_txt: Phonological implications of covert articulatory variation
awd_abstract_narration:
The most obvious difference between spoken languages is that they sound different from one another. The sounds of language interact with each other according to patterns that can be attributed to the human vocal tract, auditory system, and memory, but these patterns vary arbitrarily from language to language and dialect to dialect. Understanding how each language and dialect came to be the way it is requires understanding how languages change. A lingering mystery is why language change occurs abruptly in certain times and places but not in others, when the phonetic motivations for language change are ever-present. Unlocking this and other puzzles about variation and change in linguistic sound systems provides a window into cognition, physiology, social interaction, and how these interact with each other.

This project is a laboratory study of language variation and change, informed by a database of phonological patterns in several hundred languages and a database of hundreds of hours of spontaneous speech from one English-speaking community. The project tests the hypothesis that the start of language change is favored by covert differences in articulation, i.e., cases where speakers of the same language produce speech sounds using their vocal tracts in different ways, even though the sounds they make are indistinguishable to listeners under most conditions. Different speakers producing the same speech in different ways is hypothesized to be an important source of variation that drives language change. The random alignment of covert articulatory differences with social structure is hypothesized to account for the abruptness and infrequency of sound change. The research team examines three known cases of covert articulatory variation in English and assesses their impact on a range of sound patterns active in Raleigh, NC. The project augments an existing collection of 200+ sociolinguistic interviews with ultrasound video of the tongue, airflow measurement from the nose and mouth, and perception data. The research team will develop tools for rapid and flexible analysis of large quantities of articulatory data. These tools will be shared publicly, with the potential to benefit other linguists, speech pathologists, and engineers. The project expands and upgrades a public database of sound patterns in several hundred languages. The speech sounds focused on by the project include ones that are challenging to English-learning children and adults. Detailed phonetic information will be shared with the speech pathology and language teaching communities. Graduate and undergraduate students working on this project will learn innovative laboratory methods and quantitative skills.

por.por_cntn:
The most obvious difference between spoken languages is that they sound different from one another. The sounds of language interact with each other according to patterns that can be attributed to the human vocal tract, auditory system, and memory, but these patterns vary arbitrarily from language to language and dialect to dialect. Understanding how each language and dialect came to be the way it is requires understanding how languages change. A lingering mystery is why language change occurs abruptly in certain times and places but not in others, when the phonetic motivations for language change are ever-present. Unlocking this and other puzzles about variation and change in linguistic sound systems provides a window into cognition, physiology, social interaction, and how these interact with each other.

This project was a laboratory study of language variation and change, exploring the idea that the start of language change is favored by covert differences in articulation, i.e., cases where speakers of the same language produce speech sounds using their vocal tracts in different ways, even though the sounds they make are indistinguishable to listeners under most conditions. The research team examined two known cases of covert articulatory variation in English and assessed their impact on a range of sound patterns active in United States English.

The speech sounds focused on by the project include "l" and "r", which are challenging to English-learning children and adults. Detailed phonetic information can be shared with the speech pathology and language teaching communities. Among the phonetic facts learned in this project are that relatively familiar cases of assimilation to "r", such as affrication in "tr" and retraction in "str" are phonologized in the investigated community and not sensitive to covert articulatory variation. However, the coarticulation between "r" and other sounds across word boundaries is sensitive to articulatory variation, in particular to variation in lip rounding. In addition to these familiar cases, the research team identified articulatory variarion in the production of "kr" clusters and gained a detailed understanding of variation in the production of "l" after vowels, which involves a pharyngeal rather than velar constriction for most speakers in most contexts.

In addition to the laboratory study, the research team developed new features for a database of phonological patterns in several hundred languages and contributed to a corpus of hundreds of hours of spontaneous speech from one English-speaking community by transcribing spontaneous speech and providing ultrasound and lip videos of a subset of the speakers in the corpus.

The research team developed tools for rapid and flexible analysis of large quantities of articulatory data, which have been shared with others and subsequently applied to studies of other languages and clinical populations. The research team was able to contribute to a dental school study of the relationship between variation in jaw proportions and speech distortion, both by sharing methodological advancements and by sharing knowledge of speech production, and this has led to a fruitful collaboration between the linguistics program and the dental school in the interest of better understanding speech outcomes for jaw surgery patients.

Graduate and undergraduate students funded on this project learned innovative laboratory methods and quantitative skills including three students' MA capstone papers and one student's PhD dissertation. Fifteen undergraduate students participated as Research Experience for Undergraduates students before going on to careers including computer science and speech-language pathology.
